Issues.Title: Add ExtractIcon functionality to Icon
Issues.Body:
This adds Icon.Extracticon to allow extracting icons from icon files and native resources from PE files at any specified resolution.

Also adds an overload to SystemIcons.GetStockIcon() to get a specified size.

Fixes #8929


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8983)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add ExtractIcon functionality to Icon" (#8983)

Issues.Title: Pause NGEN to avoid CPU interference during the run
Issues.Body:
Logs for #8952 showed copies of **mscorsvw** running in the background. This change pauses the NGEN queue to prevent **mscorsvw** from consuming CPU and potentially interfering with the integration tests.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8982)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Pause NGEN to avoid CPU interference during the run" (#8982)

Issues.Title: [Tracking] Remove suppressions against Obsolete methods
Issues.Body:
This is tracking issue related to the [comment ](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8967#discussion_r1164758407)  and [comment ](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8967#discussion_r1164758407)

Obsolete suppression needs to be revisited and mark appropriate public methods obsolete.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Tracking] Remove suppressions against Obsolete methods" (#8984)

Issues.Body:
null

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Record processes active at the start of each test" (#8977)

Issues.Title: Automatically retry integration tests on failure
Issues.Body:
Re-runs just the integration test step up to one more time if a test failure occurs. Helps prevent flakiness in the system from impacting CI runs, but doesn't have any impact on developer scenarios.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8981)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Automatically retry integration tests on failure" (#8981)

Issues.Title: Resolve more pending test issues in System.Drawing
Issues.Body:
Removes suppressions that were for non-Windows platforms and adds tolerance support for ARM related floating point variance.

- Update ValidateBitmapContent helper to hash the raw image byte data instead of the entire serialized image to allow for variance of non-essential image data.
- Refactor comparison code into new `ComparisonHelpers` support class.
- Introduce a `FloatingPointToleranceComparer` to allow comparing float arrays with tolerance (to allow for ARM floating point differences in tests).
- Also add some float `AssertExtensions` for `RectangleF`.
- Adds a check to validate that we successfully got the screen HDC in Graphics.CopyFromScreen.
- Adds `ReadOnlyTheoryData` to ensure that common test data doesn't get modified and reworks test data attributes to be simpler and utilize a new raw `TestData` helper class.
- Rename `NumberData` to `IntegerData`.
- Add a GlobalUsings to TestUtilities test project.


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8957)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Resolve more pending test issues in System.Drawing" (#8957)

Issues.Title: Simplify code using RECT/Rectangle conversions
Issues.Body:
An implicit conversion `RECT` ⇆ `Rectangle` already existed in code. This change simplifies code manually converting between these types to instead rely on this operator.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8975)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Simplify code using RECT/Rectangle conversions" (#8975)

Issues.Title: Restore the cursor position at the end of each integration test
Issues.Body:
Many of the integration tests move the mouse as part of the test implementation. This change updates the base control helper to record the mouse position at the start of the test and restore it at the end.

I verified locally that this implementation works even when the mouse is initially on a different monitor in multi-monitor configurations.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8960)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Restore the cursor position at the end of each integration test" (#8960)

Issues.Title: Add UIA Toggle pattern to ToolStripButton
Issues.Body:
Fixes #8961


## Proposed changes

* Added Toggle pattern support for ToolStripButton
* Disabled pattern support for PropertyGridToolStripButton (e.g. "Categorized", "Alphabetical" buttons on a PropertyGrid) because they may have `Checked = true`, but will not behave like a toggle button in that case. Instead they behave like radio buttons and screen readers already announce their selected state
* Added unit tests
* Added `TabStop = true` for tool strips on a test form to make them selectable via keyboard for easier testing. The form already contained ToolStripButton-s with different checked states so there was no need to add it.

## Customer Impact

- Screen readers will announce toggle state of a checkable `ToolStripButton`

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Unit tests
- Manual testing

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->

### Before

Screen reader announcements for a ToolStrip with following buttons:
* toolStripButton1 with `CheckState = CheckState.Checked` 
* toolStripButton2 with `CheckState = CheckState.Unchecked` and `CheckOnClick = true`
* toolStripButton3 with `CheckState = CheckState.Indeterminate`

Narrator:

> toolStripButton1, button, 
> toolStripButton2, button, 
> toolStripButton3, button, 

NVDA:

> toolStripButton1  button
> toolStripButton2  button
> toolStripButton3  button

JAWS:

> toolStripButton1 Button
> To activate press spacebar.
> toolStripButton2 Button
> To activate press spacebar.
> toolStripButton3 Button
> To activate press spacebar.

Toggle state is not announced anywhere.

### After

Narrator:

> toolStripButton1, button, on,
> toolStripButton2, button, off,
> toolStripButton3, button, indeterminate,

NVDA:

> toolStripButton1  toggle button  pressed
> toolStripButton2  toggle button  not pressed
> toolStripButton3  toggle button  half pressed

JAWS:

> toolStripButton1 Button checked
> To activate press spacebar.
> toolStripButton2 Button not checked 
> To activate press spacebar.
> toolStripButton3 Button not checked partially checked 
> To activate press spacebar.

All screen readers announce toggle state.

 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- .NET 8.0.100-preview.4.23202.1
- Windows 11

Issues.Title: Make sure to invoke GetCursorPos after moving mouse
Issues.Body:
For some reason, I found out a long time ago that sometimes a call to `MoveMouseTo` wouldn't actually move the mouse until a call to `GetCursorPos` occurred. I don't remember the context for this realization anymore, but I included a link to the earliest known instance of this pattern.

I _believe_ the observation occurred because tests were being flaky. After I added the call to `GetCursorPos` to assert that the cursor was moving to the correct location, the tests always passed. Removing the assertion caused them to be flaky again.

This pull request also rewrites `DragMouseBy` to invoke `DragMouseTo` instead. Based on the `SendInput` documentation, [relative mouse movements are affected by the OS settings for mouse speed and acceleration](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/winuser/nf-winuser-mouse_event#remarks), which is not desirable for tests.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8956)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Make sure to invoke GetCursorPos after moving mouse" (#8956)

Issues.Title: SetWindowsHookEx API is not working for mouse actions in .NET7.0
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.Net7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes , it is working in .net6.0 and earlier versions

### Issue description

The mouse action is not captured by the SetWindowsHookEx API in .Net7.0 which works in the earlier version

### Steps to reproduce


[WinFormsApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11198683/WinFormsApp1.zip)

- Run the attached sample
- Perform the mouse action(mouse move, mousedown, Mouse up)
- The Writeline operation in the method MouseHookProc will not be performed

Note- These will be working in .NET6.0 and earlier version
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "SetWindowsHookEx API is not working for mouse actions in .NET7.0" (#8965)

Issues.Title: Remove remaining uses of Interop.VK in favor of CsWin32's VIRTUAL_KEY
Issues.Body:
This is the second of four changes to eliminate the dependency or InputSimulatorPlus and allow us to apply MOUSEEVENTF_MOVE_NOCOALESCE to all simulated mouse actions in integration tests.

This change is not strictly required. A subsequent PR uses `IsExtendedKey`, but if this change is not desired I could update that code to cast its `VIRTUAL_KEY` to `short` for the call.

Follow-up to #8959

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://portal.fabricbot.ms/api/codeflow?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/8963)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Remove remaining uses of Interop.VK in favor of CsWin32's VIRTUAL_KEY" (#8963)

Issues.Title: [Meta/Repository] Guidelines on submitting designer-related issues
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

N/A

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

N/A

### Issue description

I see that the [designer-related issue template](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/bug_report_designer.yml) was recently added, however, the README doesn't acknowledge this and still asks to file issues through Visual Studio:

https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/21c401d08a57af296089bd1ff41e46d77082222b/README.md?plain=1#L19-L25

What are the latest recommendations on this? If filing an issue on GitHub is no longer discouraged, perhaps the README should be updated.

This is all assuming the person doesn't have access to the designer repository.

### Steps to reproduce

N/A
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Meta/Repository] Guidelines on submitting designer-related issues" (#8962)

Issues.Title: Screen readers do not announce checked state of ToolStripButton
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 8

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No

### Issue description

Similar to https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/8307, we need to implement [Toggle UIA pattern](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/winauto/uiauto-implementingtoggle) for `ToolStripButton`, which would allow screen readers to announce the checked state.

#### Current Behavior

For a ToolStrip with following buttons:
* toolStripButton1 with `CheckState = CheckState.Checked` 
* toolStripButton2 with `CheckState = CheckState.Unchecked` and `CheckOnClick = true`
* toolStripButton3 with `CheckState = CheckState.Indeterminate`

Narrator reads only button names, without checked state:
> toolStripButton1, button, 
> toolStripButton2, button, 
> toolStripButton3, button, 


#### Expected Behavior

Screen readers should announce button's checked state:
> toolStripButton1, button, on, 
> toolStripButton2, button, off, 
> toolStripButton3, button, indeterminate,

### Steps to reproduce

1. Add `ToolStripButton`-s to a `ToolStrip` and make buttons checkable: set `CheckOnClick` property to true or `CheckState` property to `Checked`
2. Start Narrator and run the app
3. Focus on tool strip, select checked button â€” Narrator will not announce that it's checked

Sample app: [ToolStripButtonsTest.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/11190660/ToolStripButtonsTest.zip)

### Additional info

For `PropertyGridToolStripButton`, which extends from `ToolStripButton`, Toggle pattern should not be implemented, because it has "radio button" control type and cannot be toggled on or off.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Screen readers do not announce checked state of ToolStripButton" (#8961)
